loans.name: Mirasol

texts.en:
Mirasol A. manages a small parcel of rice field. She works all day and shares her harvest with her two children. Whatever products she has from her farm are mostly saved for family consumption and the rest is sold to rice traders. In addition to a rice farm, she also sells fish.

She would like to expand her business. Funding will help her buy fertilizers and seeds for her rice farm, and also to buy additional fish to resell.

She chose CEVI because she likes how the program is being implemented. She also likes the micro-insurance coverage in CEVI.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seeds for rice farm and fish to resell

loans.name: Tusitukire Wamu Women's Group, Mpigi

texts.en:
54-year-old Margaret K.'s affiliation is with Tusitukire Wamu Group, Mpigi. Margaret, who is a widow and a mother of eight, says she runs a rental and farming business. This diligent lady has been selling poultry for the last decade in Mpigi.

Margaret was previously a housewife. She was also doing some cattle keeping, though it was not her real business. She later came to the realization that to better her circumstances, she needed go hammer and tongs at the idea of setting up her own enterprise. It was about that time that she decided to get into that “walk the walk” stride as she took root.

With this loan she says she is going to procure more chicken mash for her poultry. This she envisions will insure the healthier growth of her chickens.

loans.use: To buy more chicken mash

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda L. is 47 years old, married with two children and is from San Francisco, Agusan del Sur. She has been a fish vendor since 1992.  She has five children. Everyday she sells fish in the street to be able to save enough money for the educational needs of her children. Rosalinda also helps her husband till their rice farm. She helps keep the farm free of weeds and pests.

She said that getting a loan from CEVI would help her expand her business. She would like to apply for a loan because this would make her business competitive and more profitable. She could use the money to buy for more fish that she could resell for profit and for purchasing farm supplies for their rice farm.

The income she will be able to generate will help her family buy an adequate supply of food and other basic needs.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies and additional fish to resell

loans.name: Roland

texts.en:
Roland S. is from the village of Olango. He is 24 years old. Roland is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, he plants and harvests rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately $207 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Roland joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 24,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. 

Roland is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be his 6th loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita L. is from San Francisco, Agusan Del Sur.  She is 42 years old. She wants to provide her family with all the things they need. She wants her children to finish school as a result of improving her family's economic living standards. 

She would like to apply for a loan at CEVI. “By having an access to funds, I could buy farm supplies and seeds. In that way, I will be able to earn a better income.”

Teresita chose CEVI as her MFI because it has a micro-insurance coverage program for all of its clients.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies and seeds

loans.name: Busunsuli Twezimbe Group-Kayunga

texts.en:
27-year-old Hadijah B. is affliated with the Busunsuli Twezimbe Group-Kayunga. 

For the last four years, she has been operating a drug pharmacy business in Kayunga town. Hadijah had no previous business resume, but she says painstaking planning and working tenaciously have been her stocks in trade. 

Hadijah, who is happily married with two school-going kids, says she also does some agriculture as a means of supplementing her profits. She says it is mostly people living within her community who are her loyal customers. 

Her profits are to the tune of 320,000 shillings monthly and she says with this loan, she is going to purchase more medications for resell.

loans.use: The purchase of more medications for resale

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose K. is 18 years old and lives in the town of Bugembe in the Jinja region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children.  She has a business of selling charcoal, which she has had for nine years.         

To help expand her business, Rose has requested a loan of 300,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase charcoal to resell.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Rose hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself.  In the future, she hopes to own a house.  

Rose is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her a job skill.

loans.use: to buy charcoal to resell

loans.name: Porfirio

texts.en:
Porfirio E. is from the village of Holy Friday. He is 54 years old. Porfirio is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, he plants and harvests rice for sale.  He has been engaged in his business for over 27 years and earns approximately $184 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Porfirio joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 29,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. 

Porfirio is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be his 6th loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Sharifah

texts.en:
Sharifah B. is 16 years old and lives in the town of Bugembe in the Jinja region of Uganda.  She is single and has three children.  Two of her children are currently in school.  Sharifah has a business of selling clothes, which she has had for four years.         

To help expand her business, Sharifah has requested a loan of 150,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more clothes to sell.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Sharifah hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees.  In the future, Sharifah hopes to own a boutique. 

Sharifah is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving on her life style.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to resell

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita B. is a 50-year-old farmer. She owns and manages a small rice field and sells her harvest to rice traders so she can to raise money for her two daughters. She wanted to expand her enterprise. She thinks that by receiving a loan from CEVI, she will be able to double the size of her yield. She will use the loan to purchase the farm supplies she needs, such as fertilizers.

She works all day to ensure productivity in her farm. She will use the additional income from her business to pay for school supplies and other fees.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
Daisy S. is 28 years old. She has been operating a small rice farm with her husband since 2009. She really wants to increase her harvest so that she will be able to meet the needs of her family. She has one child who is 8 months old. She dreams that her daughter will have a better future when she grows up. 

She would like to apply for a loan of Php 4,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizers. This will make her farm productive and provide a better income for her family.

She joined CEVI because it has a micro-insurance coverage for all of its clients.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and fertilizers

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.en:
Rogelio P. is from the village of Tabo-o, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. He is 55 years old, is married and has with adult children. To make a living, Rogelio plants and harvests a variety of vegetables for sale. Rogelio has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rogelio joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rogelio is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. 

This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rogelio from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Delfa

texts.en:
Delfa M. lives in San Francisco, Agusan del Sur. She is he mother of four children and she is passionate about taking care of the needs of her family. She has had a rice farm store since 2007. She does her best to help her husband earn a living for their family. 

She would like to apply for a loan of Php 4,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the money to expand her business and buy fertilizers and other farm supplies. In that way, she believes that she will be able to increase her profits.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Yin

texts.en:
Yin O. is 52 years old and has been selling a few fresh fish in the busy local market for more than nine years. She sells fish that she buys from her wholesale supplier and other fishermen. She was married, but divorced her husband when her children were very young. She now lives with her three children who also sell fish. 

Yin O. runs her business well because she has public relations skills that she uses with her customers. Yin O. wishes to have more funds to increase her capital, which will allow her to improve her profits. This is why she has decided to ask for a loan from Kiva to purchase more fish to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Hazel

texts.en:
Hazel P. is from the town of San Francisco, Agusan Del Sur. She is 28 years old and has been a farmer since 2008. She has 3 children. She works so hard from morning to evening to be able to save enough money for her family.

Funding from CEVI will help her to expand her business more. She would like to apply for a loan of Php 4,000. This will make her farm more productive and profitable. The loan will be used to buy farm supplies.

The income she will be able to generate will help her family buy an adequate supply of food and other basic needs.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita L. is from the village of Naga, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 44 years old and has four adult children. Lolita is separated from her spouse. To make a living, Lolita plants and harvests a variety of vegetables for sale. Lolita has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lolita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lolita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Lolita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Lolita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce G., 25 years old, is from the town of San Francisco, Agusan Del Sur. She is a farmer and rice is her main crop. She is doing the best she can to earn enough money to meet the needs of her family.

She would like to apply a loan from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and seeds. The loan will help her to expand her business and increase her harvest and income. 

She said she likes the CEVI program because she is covered with by their micro-insurance program.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and seeds

loans.name: Oyunchimeg

texts.en:
Oyunchimeg is a 53-year-old, single mother who lives with her daughter in small wooden house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. 

She has been operating a used clothes retail business since 2008 with her daughter. Her store is located next to her home. After succeeding to achieve stable operations, she used her earnings to purchase construction materials to fix her house.  

This is her sixth Kiva loan through Credit Mongol. She is planning to build a bigger grocery store in her yard. She has good communication skills and her business is very important to her. She is requesting loan to purchase some more clothes and increase her working capital.

loans.use: Purchase more clothing to sell and to increase her working capital

loans.name: Forkland Group

texts.en:
Bartazar K. is in his early 20s and is single. Bartazar runs a general store. The store is open between 6am and 10pm and earns him a good monthly profit. 

This will be Bartazar's fifth loan with Tujijenge Tanzania. He used his previous loans to buy a motorcycle and open another general store nearby. These loans were all successfully repaid. With this loan, he aims to start building his own store and stop renting. 

Bartazar's dream is to travel overseas and buy clothes and shoes for a good sale.

Bartazar will share this loan with his loan group Forkland, which totals 19 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying the loans.

In the picture, Bartazar can be seen second from left in a blue shirt, in the back row.

loans.use: To start building his own store.

loans.name: Lelith

texts.en:
Lielith Bandivas owns a small (1-hectare / 2.5-acre) rice field. She tills the land and shares her harvest with her two sons. Most of the products of her farm are used for family consumption. The rest are sold to rice traders. In addition to a rice farm, she also wants to explore other income areas.

Funding from CEVI will help her to buy fertilizers and seeds. It will also help her to expand her business. She chose CEVI as her MFI because it has a micro-insurance coverage program for all its clients.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Nasimu

texts.en:
Nasimu N. is 19 years old and lives in the town of Lugazi in the Mukono region of Uganda.  She is married and has 1 child.  None of her children is currently in school. Nasimu has a business selling clothes. She has been in this business for 2 years.         

To help expand her business, Nasimu has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase clothes.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Nasimu hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself.  In the future, Nasimu hopes to expand her business even more.    

Nasimu is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to save.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joice is a resident of Kisii Town in western Kenya. She is 41 years old and a mother of seven children, all of whom are attending school. She has been doing mixed farming and sells her bananas, maize, beans, tea and vegetables to the local market.

She has applied for this loan of 45,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She believes this loan will make her have a steady flow of income to educate her children. She aspires to have three dairy cows and run a bigger retail shop than the one she is doing now.

She sees lack of finances and costly pesticides as the greatest impediment to the business.

loans.use: Purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Lulitte

texts.en: Lulitte L. is from the village of Mialem, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 36 years old. Lulitte is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Lulitte raises livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising cows for sale. Lulitte has been engaged in her business for over 17 years and earns approximately 1,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Lulitte joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lulitte is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase medication for her livestock. This will be the first loan taken out by Lulitte from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase medication for her livestock

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 31-year-old married woman from Lebanon. A mother of two school-age children, she started her business by selling accessories from her home. Today she is the proud owner of an accessories and perfume shop. She has been working hard in her store for the past five years. She helps her husband, who works as a carpenter, with the family expenses and helps to pay for her children's school fees. 

Today, she is requesting a loan of $1200 from Ameen S.A.L., a Kiva field partner, to further diversify her merchandise selection of new accessories and provide a variety of perfumes. In the future, she plans to expand her business so she can sell bags and gadgets in her shop.

loans.use: To further diversify her merchandise selection

loans.name: Encarnacion

texts.en: Encarnacion E. is from the village of Mialem, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 63 years old. Encarnacion is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Encarnacion raises livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising cows for sale. Encarnacion has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 500 Philippines pesos a month from it. In 2010, Encarnacion joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Encarnacion is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the first loan taken out by Encarnacion from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Kanyogoga Bakyara Tukore Group

texts.en:
Ronald K. is the leader of his lending group, Kanyogoga Bakyara, in Mubende. He is 36 years old and married with three children. Ronald has an agriculture business where he sells produce from Kanyogoga and his main customers are the people in his locality. He has always been involved in the farming business and due to the high demand, he has succeeded in what he does. 

Ronald needs a loan to be able to buy a camera so that he can also take photos around his area for a fee.

loans.use: Buying a camera to start taking photos

loans.name: Prudencia

texts.en: Prudencia S. is from the village of Gata Daku, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 69 years old. Prudencia is married and has eight adult children. To make a living, Prudencia runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Prudencia has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2004, Prudencia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Prudencia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from GDMPC. Prudencia is requesting a new loan of 41,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Prudencia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To repair her house

loans.name: Danilo

texts.en:
Danilo D. C., Sr. is from the village of Saranay, Cabatuan, Isabela. He is 62 years old. Danilo is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Danilo owns and operates a  fishing business, raising tilapia and selling it to the market and to community members. Danilo has been engaged in his business for more than 13 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month. 

In 2007, Danilo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his business and living situation. Danilo has successfully repaid a previous loan  from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional fish to sell. Danilo is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This will be the eighth loan taken by Danilo from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement his family's income. 

About ASKI: 
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Genelyn

texts.en:
Genelyn L., age 33, sells firewood products in her local community. Genelyn has been engaged in this business for over four years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. She and her husband have five school-aged children and live in the village of Romarate, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. 
 
In 2007, Genelyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services. She wanted to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Genelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Genelyn is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Genelyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional firewood products to sell

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn E., age 34, raises raises livestock - specifically cattle - to offer for sale. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over 13 years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month. She and her husband have two school-aged children and live in the village of Mialem, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. 

Earlier this year, Jocelyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services. She wished to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Jocelyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small business entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The purchase and insurance of a dairy cow

loans.name: Marichu

texts.en:
Marichu D., age 31, provides Internet services in her local community of the village of Romarate, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. Marichu has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 14,200 PHP a month. She and her husband have two school-aged children.
 
In 2007, Marichu joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services. She hoped to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Marichu has successfully repaid a previous loan of 50,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. Marichu is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Marichu from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her Internet services business

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian S., age 58, offers transportation servies in her local community. Vivian has been engaged in her business for over a year now and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. Vivian is widowed and has two school-aged children. The family lives in the city of Las Aguada Ozamiz. 
 
Earlier this year, Vivian joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services. Her goal was to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Vivian is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to repair her vehicle for better service. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Vivian from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair her vehicle for better transportation service

loans.name: Yem

texts.en:
Mrs. Yem C., 29 years old, is married (Her husband is pictured.) and the mother of a young child who is enrolled in school. To earn a living, Mrs. Yem C. is an internal staff member working in the garment industry. Her husband has a small business where he sells cooking supplies in and around the provinces of Cambodia.  

Mrs. Yem C. thinks that her husband's trade is a very profitable one, and it also provides the family with a good standard of living. Recently, her husband has lacked funds to buy additional products to better meet the needs of his customers. Mrs. Yem C. would like to borrow some money for her husband to purchase more products to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 30-year-old married man from Lebanon. He lives with his wife and mother. He has been working as a men's hairdresser for the past fifteen years. In 2005, he opened his own barber shop and started working independently. Due to his long experience in this occupation, he has a good number of clients passing by his shop. In addition to his haircutting service, he also sells gels and men’s perfumes in order to reinforce his business and his income. 

Today, he is requesting a loan of $1200 from Ameen s.a.l., a Kiva field partner, to increase his merchandise of perfumes and hair supplies. In the future, he hopes to open a new salon in order to expand his business into other areas.

loans.use: To increase his merchandise of perfumes and hair supplies

loans.name: Caltex Development Group, Mubende

texts.en:
N. Frister, age 44, belongs to the Caltex development group. Frister operates a tailoring business in which she makes and mends clothes in Kasenyi. In addition to tailoring, she also sells produce. From both businesses, she is able to earn 300,000/= in weekly profits. She and her husband have three children, two of whom are enrolled in school.

Frister is requesting a loan in order to be able to buy more clothing materials, both for to offer for sale and to use for making clothes that she will then sell. She is a hard-working and determined lady who was trained in the tailoring trade before starting on her business. Her dream is to continue educating her children and to be able to secure a permanent place in town from which to operate her business.

loans.use: To buy clothing materials for her tailoring business

loans.name: Erma

texts.en:
Erma B. is from the village of Alimannao, Peñablanca, Cagayan. She is 54 years old. Erma is married and has seven grown children. To make a living, Erma owns and operates a general store, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Erma has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Erma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Erma has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. Erma is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fourth loan taken by Erma from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to financially support her family. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Germelina

texts.en:
Germelina P., from the village of Tabo-o, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental, is 42 years old, married and has grown children. To make a living, Germelina has been planting and harvesting rice for sale for over three years, earning approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Germelina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC that was used as additional capital for her business, she is now requesting her third loan in the amount of 25000 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Germelina plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en:
Emelia R., from the city of Gala Ozamiz, is 38 years old, married and has five grown children. To make a living, Emelia has owned and operated a transportation services business in the local community for over a year, earning approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Emelia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is now requesting her first loan of 15000 PHP to repair an existing vehicle for better service. Emelia plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: To repair existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Jyldyz's Group

texts.en:
Jyldyz S. is the leader of this group loan. She is a resident of Balykchi, a nice town in the Isykul region. Jyldyz is 26 and married. Her husband works in construction. Together they are bringing up a daughter and a son. Both children are preschool age.  

Two years ago, with the initial investment of 15000 KGS, Jyldyz rented a space and started to sell clothes to make money. In this way she earns 10500 KGS per month. That profit made it possible for her to save money and purchase her own space. 

Jyldyz applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase jeans, sportswear and other clothes in order to increase the turnover of her products. In the future she wants to expand her business and build a big house for her family.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff

loans.use: To purchase clothes for sale

loans.name: Lass

texts.en:
Lass P., 55, is a low-income woman living in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. To earn a living, Lass P. sells dried fish in the busy local market.  She also buys fresh fish and dries them and sells them to her regular customers. Her husband helps her in the same business. She  typically generates an income of US $3 each day to meet her family’s living expenses.

This couple has three children, one of whom is married and the other two single; both are employed in a garment factory. Lass P. hopes to enlarge her business and is applying for a US $1200 loan to be used to buy more fish to sell in order to add more profit and support her family with a more comfortable life.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma D., from the city of Gala Ozamiz, is 45 years old, married, and has 10 grown children. To make a living, Elma owns and operates a business venture planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Engaged in her business for over a year, she earns approximately 2000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Elma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her first loan in the amount of 10000 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Constance

texts.en:
Constance is a twenty-eight year old woman. She is married and has four children. They live in a rented house in Fort Portal, Uganda. She wants to own a permanent house for residence and a sustainable income-generating venture. 

She has been operating a bar for seven years. The business has grown over time amidst challenges in finances. Nevertheless, she looks forward to owning a popular bar in town. Constance needs the loan to purchase beer, because the festive season is fast approaching.

loans.use: To buy beer to sell during the festive season

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena O., age 46, operates a pedicab transport services business. Elena has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. She is widowed and has eight grown children. She lives in the village of Lapinig, Kapatagan, Lanao del Norte. 
 
In 2009, Elena joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services. She wanted to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Elena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used  to repair her vehicle for better service. Elena is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase tires and other necessary accessories. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Elena from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tires and other necessary accessories for her transportation business

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter hails from Kisii Town in western Kenya, where he is engaged in mixed farming. He sells his produce of bananas, maize, tea, beans, and vegetables at the local market. He has five children, two of whom attend school.

He has applied for this loan of 45,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo in order to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He hopes the cow will produce enough milk for family consumption and that it will help him earn more so that he may educate his children. He aspires to to have three dairy cows and run a retail business within the local market in five years' time.

His challenge is hostile weather conditions, particularly the hailstorms and droughts that affect his crops.

loans.use: The purchase and insurance of a dairy cow

loans.name: Mat

texts.en:
Mat D., 27 years old, owns a small house and a grocery shop, where she sells many items, including cooking ingredients, sweets, soft drinks, and plastic products. Mat D. retails her inventory to people who are passing by and are also to neighbors who live near her house. She has been running her grocery store for a long time and earns an average of $6 a day. 

To making additional income, she also feeds a few chickens behind her house. Her husband is a local fisherman. This couple now lives with two children who go to school. 

Mat D. has applied for a loan from HKL, a Kiva field partner, to purchase additional chickens to raise.

loans.use: To purchase additional chickens to raise

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina A., age 22, is a rice farmer. She earns her living by planting and harvesting rice to offer for sale. Rosalina has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. She is unmarried and lives in the village of Campo 4, Ramon Magsaysay, Zamboanga del Sur. 
 
In 2009, Rosalina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services. She hoped to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Rosalina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional seeds and seedlings to raise. Rosalina is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Rosalina from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure for her rice field

loans.name: Loreto

texts.en:
Loreto B. is from the village of Cebunig, Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. He is 27 years old. Loreto is married and has one infant child. To make a living, Loreto owns & operates a service-based services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from operating tricycle transport services. Loreto has been engaged in his business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Loreto joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Loreto has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to repair existing vehicle for better service. Loreto is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This will be the second loan taken out by Loreto from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: to purchase tires and other accessories

loans.name: Deus

texts.en:
Deus is a fifty-one-year-old married man with five children who lives in Fort Portal, Uganda. He longs to educate all his children to get a bachelor's degree as minimum qualification. 

He has a retail shop and has been in business for ten years now despite challenges in capital and bad debts. However he has made tremendous progress, beginning as a door-to-door hawker and now renting a shop. Deus needs the loan to buy sugar, soap, rice and cooking oil to sell.

loans.use: To buy soap, sugar, rice, and cooking oil to sell in his shop

loans.name: Meriam

texts.en:
Meriam M. is from the village of Waterfall, Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 48 years old. Meriam is married and has 7 adult children. To make a living, Meriam owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling spices in the local community. Meriam has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Meriam joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Meriam has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Meriam is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Meriam from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Kalamba Tukore Group

texts.en:
W. Yusuf is the leader of his lending group of Kalamba Tukore in Mubende. He is 48 years old and married with five children of whom three are in school. He also takes care of other dependents. Yusuf has a laundry business where he cleans and washes clothes, shoes and bags for his clients in Kalamba Town. 

Yusuf says that his customers are all people with laundry needs and he is able to make 50,000/= as weekly profits. The cleaner is his only business and hence he puts all his dedication into it. Before his current business, Yusuf was working for a construction company and he does not regret the move he made. He needs a loan to be able to buy a cow that will later give him milk for sale. He is straight-forward and open-minded and this is crucial in his business.

loans.use: Buy a cow that will give him milk for sale

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
Marcelina R. is from the village of Waterfall, Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 50 years old. Marcelina is married and has one child. To make a living, Marcelina owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Marcelina has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Marcelina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marcelina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. Marcelina is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase breeding livestock. This will be the third loan taken out by Marcelina from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Ermanie

texts.en:
Ermanie E. is from the village of Punta, Pana-on, Misamis Occidental. She is 37 years old. Ermanie is married and has 7 school-aged children. To make a living, Ermanie owns & operates transportation services. Ermanie has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Ermanie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ermanie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Ermanie is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This will be the third loan taken out by Ermanie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.
