loans.name: Enkhtuya

texts.en:
Mrs. Enkhtuya is 52 years old and lives with her husband, four children and one granddaughter in a rented apartment in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They used to have a small family house which they sold to send their eldest daughter to Japan to study. She is completing her studies next year.

Since 2004, Mrs. Enkhtuya has been running a secondhand clothing retail business. Each month she buys bundles of secondhand clothes from wholesalers, who bring them from developed countries and sell them in the local market. Secondhand clothes are in good demand in the country, especially for people who can’t afford to buy brand new clothes.  Recently she started to retail brand new clothing as well. In the future she is planning to specialize in new clothing only.

Her children are growing and three of them already have jobs, which helps the family’s income.

The reason she is applying for a loan is she wants to buy a desktop computer for family use.

loans.use: wants to buy a desktop computer for her children and family to use

He sees himself opening other branches in the future. Evanson has requested a loan of 90,000 KES to buy a scooter and a bicycle for goods distribution.

texts.en:
Mr. Khishigbat is 32 years old and lives with his wife Erdenechimeg (who is pregnant) and infant daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They live in a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife stays at home taking care of his daughter.

He has been operating a grocery store since 2008.  His store is located in a good location where there are always many people around. He began his business a few years ago by operating a small booth, and purchased his own family car with his earnings.

Khishigbat recently started to operate an auto repair shop with his friend as well. He is a very busy and energetic person. The loan will be used to increase his working capital.

loans.use: To increase his working capital.

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean B. is from the village of Villa Verde, Balulang, Cagayan de Oro City. She is a 25 year old widow. To make a living, Jean owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling dried fish & shrimp in the local community. Jean has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Jean joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jean has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Jean is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional dried fish to sell. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Jean from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.name: Antony

texts.en:
Antony is a 30-year-old married man. He sells scrap metals so as to earn a living. Besides that, he is a mechanic. He has been able to grow his business through Faulu Kenya because he has been taught how to manage a business. He hopes to expand his business and buy a piece of land in the future.  

He has requested 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy scrap metals and enlarge his store where he stores the metals.

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Farming is big in Surallah, where Josefina lives. She is also a farmer like most people in her town. She plants rice and corn crops and also some pineapples. She sells her harvest to the market. She wants to improve her harvest and earn more. Her one child, who is 19 years old, is in college now. Josefina wants to ensure her child's college education so she saves for school fees.

Josefina needs seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. Providing these would improve her harvest and her income. She applied for a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos from CEVI, a Kiva partner. This loan would be very helpful in buying the farm inputs Josefina needs.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Hardworking mother, these characteristics simply describe Helen Miquel of Pajo, Libertad, Antique, Philippines. She is 38 years old and married to Artus M., a laborer. They are blessed with three children: Yvone Grace, Aira Jane, and Vince Henson.

She has been an active and very good member of ASHI Antique Northwest Branch for almost three years. As a member, she maintains her very good performance because she is aspiring to borrow a larger amount of capital someday.

Helen is a mother who always dreams of a good future for her children and she wants to give the best for them. She dreams that someday all of their children will finish their studies until college. That is why from now on they are starting to save for the future of their children.

For her next loan, she is applying for PHP 24,000. This will be used to purchase a new fishing net so that they will get more fish and therefore have a bigger income. The income that they will be earning from this business will be a great help for them to sustain their basic needs.

loans.use: To buy a new fish net

location.town: Macasandig, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Emly

texts.en:
Emly L. is 57 years old, married and supports her family by operating a fishing business. She lives in Purok 2, Brgy. Pasil, EB Magalona, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fishing business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 14,000. 

Emly is now borrowing PHP 19,500 to purchase fishing equipment. This will be her 9th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 18,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Emly aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and to ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha V. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Paho, Brgy. Pateño, Cauayan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: fish vending and a variety store. Her husband, Rey, who is 48 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living, and also helps with his wife's business activities. They have three children, who are between 25 and 29 years old. Editha joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past ten loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Editha has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 25,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15,000, improving the family's standard of living. This time, for her eleventh loan, she is borrowing PHP 28,000, which she intends to use as additional capital for her fish selling business so that she can continue to save up for the future expansion of her business and home repairs. Editha V. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon -- a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team.

loans.use: To fund the operation of her fish selling business.

loans.name: Cory

texts.en:
Cory N. from San Jose, Antique, Philippines is a very responsible mother who is married to a responsible husband, Danilo N.. They are blessed with four children: David, Danica, June Klien and Dianne Claire. All of their children are still studying.

Though her husband works as a seaman, she is not contented with the income of her husband because according to her, “As their children grow, their needs are also bigger, especially their educational needs". So she needs to help her husband.

Cory is a mother who always thinks towards the future of her children and she wants to give her best to them.

Being a member, she maintains her good performance. That is why she is the one who is awarded a bigger loan in their center.

As of now, her previous business is still there and improving. That is why for her next loan, she is applying for PHP 30,000, which will be used as additional capital for her variety store.

Cory and Danilo really work hard to earn an income in order to sustain the increasing needs of the family. 

Her greatest dream is that their children will finish their studies until college and have a bigger income out of her business so that they will become financially stable.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina D. is a married woman who lives in Purok 1, Brgy. Bongalonan, Basay, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating three businesses: livestock raising, food vending, and fish vending. Her husband Rufino, who is 56 years old, works as a carpenter to earn his living, and also helps with his wife's business activities. They have three children, who are 15 to 30 years old.

Angelina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Angelina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 9,500, improving the family's standard of living. This time, for her fifth cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 20,000, with which she intends to fund her livestock raising operations, so that she can continue to save up for the education of her children and also buy a new lot to build a house for her family. Angelina D. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon -- a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team.

loans.use: To fund the operation of her livestock business.

loans.name: Tiarogot Ole

texts.en: Tiarogot Ole K. is 39 years old. He is married to Kinyikita K. and he is a father of six children between the ages of four and twenty. Tiarogot is a businessman involved in buying and selling sheep in his area for the past six years. He learned about KADET from a colleague who is already a KADET LTD registered client. This will be his first loan which he is planning to use to buy more sheep to sell after a short period of time. He hopes to use the profit from this loan to pay for his children’s education and his basic needs. Tiarogot’s future dream is that he will be able to sell the sheep and become a renowned businessman in his residence area. He is a hard working man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: To buy more sheep to sell.

loans.name: Irenia

texts.en:
Irenia J. is from the village of Macasandig, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 51 years old, married and has 3 adult children. Irenia owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods & snack food. She has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2000, Irenia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products. She is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital

location.town: Macasandig, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Aidah

texts.en:
Aidah N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Bulenga in the Kampala west region of Uganda.  She is single and has 1 child who is not currently attending school. Aidah has been involved in a hotel business for 2 years. She has a clothes salon.   

To help expand her business, Aidah has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase clothes.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Aidah hopes to generate greater profits and to buy food. In the future, Aidah hopes to own a boutique.  

Aidah is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving on her business.

loans.use: to purchase clothes.

loans.name: Nanecia

texts.en:
Nanecia B. is from the village of Macasandig, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 51 years old, married and has 2 adult children. Nanecia owns & operates a specialized retail store where she buys and sells boiled duck eggs, also known as balot. She has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Nanecia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding her business. She is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Gorret

texts.en:
Gorret N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Bulenga in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is single and has 2 children, one of whom is currently in school. Gorret has been involved in a hotel business for 3 years. She sells clothes  

To help expand her business, Gorret has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase food and drinks. With the help of the loan from BRAC, she hopes to generate greater profits and to buy food.  In the future, Gorret hopes to buy food. 

Gorret is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving on her business.

loans.use: to buy food and drinks

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence N. is in the taxi transport business in Eldoret, Kenya. She is 27 years old, married to Julius Limo and has one child who is one year old. Her husband is also a businessman in the same transportation sector, he therefore also contributes to the family's income. From the transport business, Florence earns KES 25,000 per month. She is applying for her first loan from KADET LTD of KES 40,000, which she plans to use to service her taxi so it will be in better condition and to buy two tires. The anticipated profits from the expanded business will be reinvested in the business. In the future, Florence hopes to own a bus with a capacity of 80 seats, which will enable her to provide for her family’s basic needs, and also see her child become enlightened through education and become successful in life.

loans.use: To service her taxi and buy two tires.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth S. is 42 years old. She is from Khwisero in Kakamega and is married to Noah. The couple has two children, aged 18 and 14. Ruth has had a cereals business for the past three years. She is applying for her first loan from KADET LTD after being introduced by a friend who is also a client here. Ruth will use the money to buy eight bags of maize to add to her stock. The profits made from this business will be used to pay school fees for her children. Her desire is to open up a nursery school in the future and diversify into that business.

loans.use: To buy 8 sacks of maize.

loans.name: Jamirah

texts.en:
Jamirah N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Bulenga in the Kampala west region of Uganda.  She is married and has 1 child who is currently in school. Jamirah has been operating a business selling food and vegetables for 1 year.         

To help expand her business, Jamirah has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase food.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Jamirah hopes to generate greater profits and to take care of herself. In the future, Jamirah hopes to own a retail shop.        

Jamirah is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by helping her improve on her business.

loans.use: to buy food

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen C. is from the village of Macasandig, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 34 years old, married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Helen owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods, and junk food in the local community. Helen has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Helen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase additional products to buy and sell. Helen is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and provide working capital. This will be the second loan that Helen has taken out from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business.

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Raymunda

texts.en:
Raymunda P. is a married woman who lives in Purok 1, Brgy. Bongalonan, Basay, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures:  selling knitted nipa palm leaves and a tailoring businesses. Her husband Jose, who is 52 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living, and also helps with his wife's businesses. They have eight children who are between 11 and 30 years old. Raymunda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 16 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Raymunda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,400, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 17th loan, she is borrowing PHP 16,000, which she intends to use to buy raw materials for the knitting of nipa leaves so that she can continue to save for the future education of her children. Raymunda P. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Annabelle

texts.en:
Annabelle S. is 44 years old, married and supports her family by operating three business ventures: a variety store, buying and selling (charcoal) and a livestock business. She lives in Purok 3, Brgy. Talacdan, Cauayan, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her variety store, buying and selling (charcoal) and livestock businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 6,000. Annabelle is now borrowing PHP 20,000 so that she can continue to purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 16th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 20,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Annabelle aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace V. is a 57-year-old lady who is married with children that she supports. Grace runs a cafe in Bombolulu, where she sells light meals and snacks to the customers who come into her café. Her business has been in operation for the last two years. 

This marks Grace's first loan from KADET LTD since joining. She plans to purchase more flour, rice and vegetables for her café business. From the anticipated profits she will expand her business and get more varieties of foods to prepare for her customers.

Her dream is to live happily and to satisfy her customers.

loans.use: to purchase more flour, rice and vegetables

Her husband Ernisto, who is 52 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have six children who are between five and 30 years old.

This time, for her 16th loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000 to buy stocks of fruits and vegetables to sell so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Wilma is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Norah

texts.en:
Norah N. is 18 years old and lives in the town of Bulenga in the Kampala west region of Uganda.  She is single and has one child who is not currently at school. Norah operates a hotel business which she has had for two years.  She sells local beer. 

To help expand her business, Norah has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase food, charcoal and millet for making local beer.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Norah hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself.  In the future, Norah hopes to study a course on hairdressing. Norah is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her job skills.

loans.use: To buy food, charcoal and millet for making local beer

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
In 11 years of membership in ASHI, Teresa D. has developed comradeship with other members of ASHI in their barangays (small districts). The institution helps her to improve not only her living conditions but also the social aspects of her life. This is very useful to her and to her project which is a funeral home.

Even at 59, her industry never fades. When her husband died, she became the one who managed the business and most of her time is spent on her business and on her children. Moreover, she has done her best to improve her business in order to sustain their basic needs.

Through her hardship, courage and industry, her three children have already finished their studies and currently they have stable jobs. 

Though her children have their own jobs, she never stops dreaming about their future. She wants her business to improve so she can help other people in the community by providing employment to them. She has also planned to help their relatives so that they will become successful someday.

For her next loan, she is applying for PHP 35,000 which will be utilized as additional capital for her business (funeral home). She wants more capital because there are times when she has customers who can’t afford to buy a coffin in cash. As she is very considerate, she lets her customers pay for the items in installments and that is why she really needs rolling capital.

She is now more dignified because there are institutions like ASHI and its field partner KIVA which believe and trust in her.

loans.use: To provide additional capital for her funeral services business

loans.name: Mdigo

texts.en:
Mdigo B. is a 24-year-old single man who runs poultry farming as his primary business and bicycle transport ("bodaboda") as his secondary business. He has been in the poultry business for the past year.

 This will be his first loan with KADET and he plans to purchase young chicks which he will keep and latter resell once they are big enough. He plans to use the anticipated profits in boosting his poultry business.

His hope is to succeed through KADET loans.

loans.use: buying young chicks to raise

loans.name: Rubielyn

texts.en:

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her poultry and snacks vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000. 

Rubielyn is now borrowing PHP 10,000 so that she can purchase more stock to sell. This will be her sixth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 8,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Rubielyn aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

loans.name: Flordeliza

texts.en:
One of Flordeliza's dreams is to see all her children finish college and have bright futures. She has five children with the eldest aged 22. She is working hard to achieve her dream. To make a living, Flordeliza owns and operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from gathering and selling seaweed to the market. 

Flordeliza joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including nets. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment including nets

loans.name: Moses Eyapan

texts.en:
Moses Eyapan E. is a 28-year-old man married to Jackline Barongo Onyancha. They have three children aged five years, two years and eight months. They live in Eldoret, Kenya. Moses sells charcoal, earning an income of Kshs 10,000 per month. He has been in this business for the past five years.

Moses was introduced to KADET LTD by a credit officer and he is applying for his first loan of Kshs 20,000 with KADET LTD. With this loan he plans to purchase 15 bags of charcoal which will add more stock to his business inventory and he will be able to maximize profits.

He hopes that with more income he is going to make to purchase a piece of land and build his own rental houses.

loans.use: To purchase 15 bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret T. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Bulenga in the Kampala west region of Uganda.  She is married and has three children all of whom are currently in school.  Margret operates a bar as a business which she has had for five years.  She also does art and craft  

To help expand her business, Margret has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more millet for making local beer. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Margret hopes to generate greater profits and buy food.  In the future, Margret hopes to own a plot. Margret is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to save.

loans.use: To buy more millet for making local beer

loans.name: Nkorana Ene

texts.en:
Nkorana Ene K. is 31 years old. She is married to Koileken Lagama and she is a mother of three school-going children. She is a farmer as well as a business lady involved in clothes-selling and she has been in the businesses for the past eight years. 

Nkorana learned about KADET through an awareness outreach done by KADET staff in her area of residence. This will be her first loan. She is planning to spend twenty thousand to buy new cloth for resale. With the profits she hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, she intends to reinvest back into the business and expand it.

Nkorana’s future dream is to open a beauty boutique in the town center. She believes she is hard-working and she only needs resources to attain her goals.

loans.use: buying new cloth to sell

loans.name: Rakita Ole

texts.en:
Rakita Ole K. is 41 years old. He is married to Talasha K. and a father of seven school-going children. He is a businessman involved in the trade of livestock, which he buys and sells at a profit.

He learned about KADET from other members in a group already registered with KADET in his area of residence. This will be his first loan, which he is planning to spend to buy more cattle for fattening and then selling. He hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand his business and become a commercial animal seller.

Rakita‘s dream is do well in the business and start dairy farming. He is a hard working man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: To buy more cattle for fattening and selling

loans.name: Toem

texts.en:
Mr. Toem C. and his wife Mrs. Yan Meak live on an island in the Mekong river about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 1977 and have eight children (four sons and four daughters). 

Toem is a farmer. His wife sells grocery items at home and assists her husband in the farming business as well. Toem is asking for a loan in the amount of $700 to purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain his farm. 

Photo: Mr. Toem C. is shown at home because he was not at the farm when photographed.

loans.use: To purchase seed, fertilizer, and pesticide for farming

loans.name: Hak

texts.en:
Mr. Hak T. is highly skilled at building stone and wooden houses. He has a few physical laborers to help provide his service. He receives a lot of orders from his clients to construct their houses. He has another partner in his wife, who appears in the picture above. She sells flowers in her community to earn additional profits. Mr. Hak T. has two children; both of them are students and dependent on him. 

Currently, Mr. Hak T. is managing his investment more smoothly. He has many regular customers who put in orders for him to build their houses. Mr. Hak T. hopes to be able to earn extra income by using a Kiva loan to purchase a machine for splitting wood in order to provide his construction services.

loans.use: To purchase a machine for splitting wood in order to provide his construction services

loans.name: Ny

texts.en:
Mr. Ny C. (shown in the photo) and his wife, Mrs. Hou Lonh, live on an Island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. The couple has been married since 1972. 

Ny is a fisherman and wooden-house repairman. His wife sells vegetables in the local market. Part of his house is broken. He wants to fix it but he does not have money.

Therefore, Ny is asking for a loan of $1,200 to make the repairs.

loans.use: To repair his house

loans.name: James Kokoyo

texts.en:
James Kokoyo O. K. is 48 years old. He is married to Rankaso K. and a father of seven school-going children. James has been a businessman involved in selling animals for the past six years.

James learned about KADET from other members in a group already registered with KADET in his area of residence. This will be his first loan, which he is planning to spend to buy more cattle for fattening and then selling them. He hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand his business and become a commercial animal seller.

James’ dream is to do well in the business and start dairy farming. He is a hard working man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: To buy more cattles for fattening and later selling them.

loans.name: Tuchukuliane Group

texts.fr: Kavira  M.  est  présidente du groupe Tuchukuliane, âgée de 46 ans, mariée, mère de 11 enfants dont l’un fut décédé. Tous ses enfants étudient. Son mari est  enseignant.  Elle vend l’huile de palme. Elle  commença son business  avec son fonds propre, plus tard, elle bénéficia de crédit de l’IMF  Hekima de 50$ vers les années 2002, après éruption du volcan Nyiragongo. Elle installe ses produits  au le marché. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec 10 bidons d’huile de palme. En plus, elle ambitionne acheter une parcelle et construire une belle maison. La cliente Kavira  M. remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique.  Il sied de signaler que ce groupe Tuchukuliane est  composé de 15 membres.
texts.en: Kavira M. is president of the Tuchukuliane group. She is 46 years old, married and mother to eleven children, one of whom is dead. All her other children are studying. Her husband is a teacher. She sells palm oil. She began her business with her own money and later on, around 2002 and after the eruption of the Nyiragongo volcano, she benefited from a loan of $50 from IMF Hekima. She sells her products at the market. This new loan will allow her to stock up with ten containers of palm oil. Her ambition is to buy a piece of land and build a beautiful house. This customer, Kavira M., thanks Hekima for its actions in favour of the poor, who have no access to classic banks. It should be noted that the Tuchukuliane group is made up of 15 members.

loans.use: Ten containers of palm oil

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a new oven

loans.name: Kieru

texts.en:
Kieru P. is 23 years old. He is married to Rankaso Kireu and the father of three school-going children. He is a businessman who has been involved in selling animals for the past six years.

Kieru learned about KADET from other members in a group already registered with KADET in his area of residence. This will be his first loan, which he is planning to spend to buy more cows for fattening and later selling them at a profit. Kieru hopes to use the profits from the proceeds of this loan to expand his business and become a commercial animal seller.

Kieru's dream is to do well in the business and start dairy farming. He is a hard working man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: To buy more cows for fattening and later selling them

loans.name: Mario

texts.en:
Mario Y. is from the town of Trinidad. He is 55 years old, married and has two children aged 16 and 14. To make a living, Mario owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Mario does his best to provide his family's needs. He also prioritizes his children's education.

Mario joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Mario is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase piglets and pig food. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement his family's income.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and pig food

loans.name: Kabuo

texts.fr: Kabuo S.  E. est entrepreneur, âgée de 30 ans, femme vivant seule, mère d’1 enfant.  Elle vend des souliers (en plastic), elle fait également le tricotage. Elle  commença son business  avec son fonds propre, capital constitué de revenu de champs des blés. Plus tard, elle bénéficia de crédit de l’IMF  Hekima de 50$. Elle installe ses produits  au long de la rue. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  200 paires des souliers. En plus, elle ambitionne acheter une machine tricoteuse. La cliente Kabuo S. remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique.
texts.en: Kabui S. E., an entrepreneur, is a thirty-year old mother of one, living alone.  She sells plastic shoes and knits.  She began her business with her own funds, the revenue generated from her wheat fields. Later, she received a 50$ loan from Hekima. She then set up her products along the road.  This new loan will allow her stock up with 200 pairs of shoes. Additionally, she aspires to buy a knitting machine.  This client, Kabuo S., thanks Hekima for favoring the poor who are excluded from traditional banking services.

loans.use: 200 pairs of shoes

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Kavira

texts.fr: Kavira  S.  Esperance est  entrepreneur, âgée de 40 ans, mariée, mère de 9 enfants. Tous ses enfants étudient. Son mari est  commerçant.  Elle vend des poissons. Elle a aussi une boutique pour renforcer son revenu.  Elle  commença son business  avec son fonds propre reçu de son mari, plus tard, elle bénéficia de crédit de l’IMF  Hekima de 50$. Elle installe ses produits  au le marché Kahembe. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  en poissons frais (4 paniers), le reste de credit sera injecté dans les activités de boutique. En plus, elle ambitionne acheter une parcelle pour ses enfants et voir ses enfants finir les études. La cliente Kavira  S. remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique.
texts.en:
Kavira S. E. is an entrepreneur, aged 40, married and the mother of nine children. All her children attend school. Her husband is a merchant. She is a fish seller. She has also a store to increase her income. She began her business with funds received from her husband. Some time later, she was granted a loan of $50 by the microfinance institution Hekima. She sells her products at a stall located at the Kahembe market.

She wants to use her new loan to buy 4 baskets of fresh fish and invest any remaining capital in her activity at the store. In addition, her goal is to buy a plot of land for her children and see them finish school. The client Kavira S. thanks Hekima for their action in favor of poor people, who are excluded from the traditional banking system.

loans.use: To buy 4 baskets of fish and stock up her store

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Olobulu Ole

texts.en:
Olobulu Ole K. is 22 years old .He is married to Kisianani Namo and the father of two children. Olobulu is a businessman involved in buying and selling bulls and he has been doing this for the last five years. 

He learned about KADET through a marketing campaign done by KADET staffs in his area of residence. This will be his first loan, which he is planning to use to buy young bulls for selling later as that business is doing much better in his area. He hopes to use the profit from this loan to acquire a small piece of land for his wife to carry out crop farming.

His dream is to become a commercial businessman and he is a young and energetic man who can do more if supported financially.

loans.use: To buy young bulls for selling later

loans.name: Bunna

texts.en:
Mrs. Bunna N. and her husband, Mr. Leak Cheun, have been married since 1992 and have six children. The family lives on an island on Mekong River around 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Bunna and her husband are farmers. They grow tomato, papaya and corn on their farmland in the village. The couple asked for a Kiva loan once before.  Now Bunna is requesting another loan of $500 to continue her farming business by purchasing seeds, fertilizer, and pesticide to maintain her vegetable farm. 

Photo: Mrs. Bunna N. is at home, not at the farm.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Martine

texts.fr: G. Martine est née en 1979 à Bopa au Bénin. Mariée à HOUNHOVI Hector, Martine est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. En plus de leurs enfants, le couple a un autre enfant à charge. La famille s'est installée depuis une douzaine d'année environs à Adogléta, un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Martine vient en aide à son mari en supportant avec lui les différentes charges familiales, grâce au revenu de son activité. Martine n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Martine vend divers condiments de sauce (tomate fraîche ou en conserve, oignons, piments, épices, etc.) et parallèlement, Martine vend des céréales dont le haricot. Martine s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et vend ses produits à son domicile. Martine exerce cette activité depuis neuf ans environs, et a déjà obtenu huit crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Martine a été victime de l'inondation récente qu'il y a eu au Bénin, mais cela ne l'a pas empêché de rembourser son crédit. Dans le but d'agrandir un peu plus son activité et d'accroître davantage ses revenus, Martine sollicite un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en: Martine G. was born in 1979 in Bopa, Benin.  Married to Hector Hounhovi, Martine is the mother of four children who are all in school.  In addition to their children, the couple take care of another child. The family has been living in Adogléta, a neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin for twelve years.  With the income of her business, Martine helps her husband provide the family expenses. Martine did not finish school, so to meet her needs, she sells condiment sauces (canned or fresh tomatoes, onions, peppers, spices, etc.). She also sells grains and beans. Marine stocks up at Dantokpa, Benin's international market, and sells products at her home.  Martine has been in business for nine years and she has already obtained eight loans through ALIDé, all of which have been repaid. Recently, Martine was the victim of the major flooding that occurred in Benin, but that did not stop her from repaying her loans. In order to expand her business and to further increase its revenues, Martine is asking for another loan through ALIDé.

loans.use: To buy Condiments and Grain

loans.name: Salaam

texts.en:
Salaam A. is a 53-year-old lady from Mlaleo. She is divorced and a mother of four children. She is a tailor by profession and she has been in the tailoring business for the last 23 years. 

This is her second loan with KADET after successfully repaying the previous one. She plans to purchase materials in readiness for orders from her clients in the area, especially in the festive season. She will use the anticipated profits to renovate her rental houses.

Her dream is to succeed in life.

loans.use: To purchase material (fabric) to use for her orders

loans.name: Yim

texts.en:
Mrs. Yim N. (shown in the photo) is a widow with six children (three sons and three daughters). Three of her children are married and live outside the family home. Two are garment factory workers and another is a solder. Mrs. N. and her family live along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penn, the capital city of Cambodia.

Yim is a farmer and grows longan and banana. She is in the process of building a house in which to stay, but the house is not yet completed. Hence, Yim is asking for a loan of $300 to finish the house.

loans.use: To finish building a house

loans.name: Christopher Kyalo

texts.en:
Christopher is 38 years old. He is married to Susan and is the father of three children ages one year, six years, and ten years respectively. He operates a tailoring shop in Wote Trading Center. This has been his primary business for the last seven years. 

He came to know about KADET through a friend who was already a member. This is his fourth loan from KADET, after successfully repaying his previous loans. He has not borrowed from other financiers before. 

With this loan, Christopher plans to buy some materials and other swwing items so that he can be able to serve his customers better. He hopes to become a major school uniform distributor in Wote and in Makueni at large.

loans.use: Christopher wants to buy some cloth and other materials

loans.name: Kry

texts.en:
Mr. Kry S. is 31 years old and his wife, Mrs. Samen Sok, is 30 years old. They have been married since 2000 and have three young sons. The family lives along National Road Number One about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Kry is a rice farmer. His wife sells Chinese noodle with soup and coffee in her village. Kry is asking for his first loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for commuting because he does not have his own transportation and very often spends a lot of money for traveling costs. He will also use a part of the loan for farming.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting and use for farming

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is 46 years old and a resident of Nyamira Town in western Kenya. He has been doing mixed farming for over twenty years and selling the milk,sugarcane and bananas that he produces to the local market. He has 4 children.

He has applied for this loan of 45,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo. This is his second loan; his first loan was for 30,000 KES. He will use this loan to purchase a dairy cow.He believes that income from the dairy will improve his family's living standard. He earns extra income from selling domestic animals. He plans to expand his farm through purchase. James experiences difficulties with animal diseases.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha S. J. is a 28-year-old woman who runs a hair salon and cosmetics shop in Mwandoni. She is married to Mohamed Abdul, who works at a clearing and forwarding company. They are blessed with one child. She has been in the salon business for the last two years. 

She has now applied for her second loan from KADET after successfully repaying the previous loan. She will purchase a new hair drier and add stock of beauty products in anticipation of a business boom in the coming festive season. She plans to use the anticipated profits to increase her business stock.

Her dream is to succeed through KADET loans.

loans.use: To purchase a new hair drier and stock beauty products

loans.name: Josée Nathalie

texts.fr: H. Josée Nathalie est née le 27 Juillet 1975 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à AKOSSOU Hervé, un fonctionnaire, Nathalie est mère de deux enfants tous scolarisés. Nathalie vit avec sa famille depuis environs quatorze ans au quartier Midombo à Cotonou. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges de la famille. Nathalie n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Pour assurer ses différentes charges, Nathalie mène comme activité la vente de produits divers (sucre, conserve de sardine et de tomate, lait, couscous, piles, produits de toilette dont les savons, papier hygiénique, etc.)à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est aussi dans ce même marché que Nathalie s'approvisionne. Nathalie exerce cette activité depuis treize ans et a bien remboursé le crédit antérieur obtenu auprès de ALIDé. Face à la demande de plus en plus grande, Nathalie souhaite augmenter le stock de ses produits et mieux répondre à sa clientèle ; raison pour laquelle Nathalie sollicite un autre crédit.
texts.en: Josée Nathalie H. was born July 27, 1975 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  Married to Hervé Akossou, an officer, Nathalie is a mother of two school age children. Nathalie has lived with her family in Midombo, a neighborhood of Cotonou, for fourteen years. The couple works together to provide for the family. Nathalie only finished primary school so to make a living, she runs a business selling various products (sugar, canned sardines and tomatoes, milk, couscous, batteries, and toiletries, including soap and toilet paper, etc.) at Dantokpa, Benin's international market. Nathalie also stocks up in this market.  She has been in business for thirteen years and has completely reimbursed the first loan provided through ALIDé. Faced with increasing demand, Nathalie wishes to increase stock and better serve her customers. This is the reason Nathalie is asking for a new loan.

loans.use: To buy diverse products (soap canned goods, sugar, milk, toiletries, etc.)

loans.name: Marie Josee

texts.en: Marie Josee is 39 years old. She is married and has four children who are between seven and thirteen years old. Her husband owns a shop. Marie Josee sells cassava and yams and has spent thirteen years in this business. She has requested a loan to buy more yams and cassava because it is in much demand by her customers. The profit from this business will be used for savings and to care for her family. She dreams of becoming a wholesaler, selling a variety of foodstuffs, in the future.

loans.use: To buy more cassava and yams to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 19-year-old single man living with his parents and six siblings. In 2008, he opened a barber shop in his home after five years of experience in this occupation. He has prepared a special room in his house to receive his clients. He works independently in his business. And in parallE., he works in a local barber shop to earn extra profit.

 In Lebanon, it is common at all levels of society for people to have multiple businesses to cover the increasing costs of food, housing, and other family expenses. His income is needed to help his father out with their expenses. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase new tools and chairs to be able to receive more clients. In the future, he is planning to open a barber shop in his town but he needs to gain more experience and put aside more savings to be able to realize this goal.

loans.use: to purchase new tools and chairs

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A., age 44, lives in Dandora, which is a lower-class estate. She sells sweet potatoes at Gikomba Market. She is married to Charles O. and together they have two sons and four daughters. She has been running this business for 10 years and makes a monthly income of Kshs 28,000.

Mary was introduced to KADET LTD by the credit officer in charge of the Eastlands office. She has applied for a loan. She will use Kshs 7,500 to buy 15 bags of sweet potatoes and Kshs 2,500 for transportation. If the loan improves her business, Mary will use the profits to pay high school fees for her son.

Mary dreams of expanding her business so she can educate all her children to university level. Mary describes herself as a hardworking and talented woman with many dreams for the future.

loans.use: To buy more sweet potatoes to sell.

loans.name: Vestine

texts.en:
Vestine is 40 years old. She is married to a taxi driver. They have two children who are between the ages of ten and sixteen. 

Vestine sells vegetables and she has been in business for twenty years. She would like to get a loan to buy more vegetables to sell, and with the profit she plans to build a house. She would very much like to do well and become a wholesaler in the future.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Belinda

texts.en:
Belinda J. is from the village of Tibanga, Iligan City. She is 36 years old. Belinda is married and has four adult-aged children. Belinda owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods, beverages, and junk foods in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Belinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Belinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Belinda is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Belinda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

location.town: Tibanga, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte
